Dear Mr. Gonzalez:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
March 11, 2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4144 Admission health screening; physical examinations.
(1) An initial health screening shall be completed for each
resident within 24 hours of admission to a facility.
One of three youth files reviewed did not have an admission health screening
completed within 24 hours. The youth was admitted on 02/18/22 and the health
screening was completed on 02/21/22.
R 400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
resident's case record:
(i) Documentation that the grievance policy was provided
as required in R 400.4132.
One of three youth files reviewed lacked documentation that the grievance policy
was provided to the youth.
2.) This facility is non-contracted with Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services therefore, MISEP requirements are not applicable.
3.) This facility is non-contracted with Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services, therefore, MDHHS Policy/MDHHS contract are not applicable.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Bethany Christian Services has four child caring institution licenses as well as
a child placing agency license. A youth transferred between different licenses,
and some of the admission documentation was not completed as the youth
was not consider a new admission. The facility was informed that youth
transferring from one license to another needs to be treated as a brand-new
admission to the program and all licensing rules apply.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Bethany Christian Services has come across some difficulties with local dental
offices treating the youth timely due to insurance/payment issues. The facility
was informed to document their attempts and maintain any written
communication to show efforts being made to schedule dental appointments.
1

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The facility had one corrective action plan during this licensing period for the Renewal
Inspection completed February 4, 2021, for rule 400.4166 (1) Discharge plan. A
corrective action plan dated February 18, 2021, was approved that included
completing a residential closing document being added to the discharge checklist.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator reported no barriers or systemic factors that have impacted
rule compliance for the facility. COVID positive staff challenged the facility’s ability to
stay in ratio, but the case manager helped cover shifts for the facility to stay in ratio.
The facility implemented independent outings into the community and helped the
youth create a resident council. The facility is renovating the lower level of the home
to increase their capacity to care for 12 youth. An inspection report completed by the
Department of Licensing and Regulatory Affairs was completed on February 16, 2022
outlining what needed to be taken care of for final approval.
Interviews
I interviewed three youth during the onsite visit. The youth interviewed reported
feeling safe, having someone to talk to at the facility and working on independent
living skills. The youth were enrolled in school. I spoke with staff who reported
feeling supported in their job and enjoying their work. There were no concerns noted
by youth or staff.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the facility continue on their regular license.
